tip: A deduction from earnings, based on the level of weekly income. The contributions made build up entitlements to certain state benefits.
Pay As You Earn is the method by which employers take away deductions, such as income tax and national insurance, before you are paid.
The amount of money you are able to earn before paying any income tax.
A form of long term investment to be used in retirement.
A sum of money paid up front to secure a product, service or property.
Someone who agrees to pay a financial commitment if the individual who took this out cannot or does not repay it.
Calculated under the assumption that any interest paid is combined with the original balance.  It can be compounded several times a year depending on the number of times interest payments are made.
APR is meant to give you the overall equivalent cost of a debt. Calculated by both the cost of the borrowing and any associated fees that are included.
Bank Accounts you are ables to take out money immediately.

of borrowing money.
A rating given to you based upon your financial history. Financial institutions use them when assessing who they should give credit to.
Non-profit making organisations set up to provide saving and borrowing facilities to local communities.
A form of credit used to buy relatively large goods. You pay back the cost over an agreed time period.
A borrowing facility on your current account that allows you to spend more than you have in the account.
Occurs when you have withdrawn more money than you have in your account, or you have taken out more than your authorised overdraft limit without agreement from the bank.
A very short term form of borrowing with very high interest rates and penalties for missed payments.
Financial institutions can have strict rules for using some of their products. If you fail to meet these then they can give this as a charge.
An agreement allowing an organisation to debit your current account with the amount you owe them on a regular basis. Often used to pay regular bills.
An instruction set up by you to your bank to pay out a regular amount to a third party, for example, to a relative or company.
Bankruptcy is a court order that you can apply for if you are in debt. Once you have been made bankrupt, an 'official receiver' takes control of your assets and deals with your creditors.
Negotiating a new loan to pay off an existing loan or loans.
The code tells your employer how much tax-free pay to give you during each pay period. Your tax code is worked out from your tax allowances and other tax adjustments.
They are means-tested allowances administered by HM Revenue and Customs. Such as Working Tax Credit and Child Tax Credit.

If you'd rather not fork out for a TV licence, you can instead watch movies and box sets via film-streaming sites and catch-up on your favourite programmes online (as long as it's not on BBC iPlayer).

There's a great loophole which lets you use it after you've turned 25. Buy a 3-year Railcard the day before your 24th birthday or a 1-year Railcard before your 26th to get the discount until you turn 27.
If you buy insurance or another product through Compare the Market, it entitles you to a year's 2for1 cinema tickets on Tuesday or Wednesday at most of the big chains.
Most store cards charge a hideous 25% interest or more. Even the best aren't cheaper than a bank's credit cards, so don't get sucked in by the sales patter.

If you return from the pub craving pizza twice a week, keep a stash of cheap frozen supermarket pizzas in your freezer. You'll save tonnes if you can avoid ordering regular takeaways!
Set up a standing order on your bank account to transfer a small amount of money into a savings account every payday.  This way you're much less likely to spend it, and even small amounts add up!
